awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Leveraging Biophysical Methods to Investigate the Interplay of Host Defense Mechanisms at Biological Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological membranes and their constituents are involved in virtually all processes vital to living organisms, including the immune response. This research investigates how several agents of the immune response combine their antimicrobial effects by interacting with each other on bacterial cell membranes. The specific agents of interest are host defense peptides and copper ions. Host defense peptides are powerful molecules that act on a broad range of pathogenic cells, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Copper ions, which are present in immune cells, can damage the cell membranes of bacteria by oxidizing their phospholipids. Interestingly, some host-defense peptides contain a copper-binding motif that enables them to bind copper and become metallopeptides. In this project, the PIs will develop new bio-physical and biochemical tools to investigate how host defense metallopeptides and copper ions may synergize their antimicrobial effects. This project has the potential to produce new principles that could be useful to design novel antimicrobial biomaterials. In addition, the project will include activities that engage college and pre-college students from diverse backgrounds in hands-on science and enhance their analytical skills. The PIs will leverage the interdisciplinary and collaborative nature of their research, and passion for scientific research to spike scientific interest in young students and prepare high school students for a successful transition to college.  

The major goal of this research is a rigorous investigation of the interplay between host defense mechanisms at biological membranes. The molecular systems of interest are membrane-interacting host defense metallopeptides and other agents of the immune response that have the potential to unify their antimicrobial effects at lipid membranes. While host defense peptides have been studied for their ability to disrupt the conformational arrangement in bacterial cell membranes, the possibility that host defense peptides and other immune agents such as copper and oxidized lipids synergize their antimicrobial effects has not been explored on a molecular level. The PIs will test this hypothesis using peptides from fish (piscidins) and ticks (ixosins). They will leverage their expertise in the characterization of membrane assemblies and harness a platform of cutting-edge biophysical techniques (solid-state NMR, neutron diffraction, surface-sensitive methods) and biological assays to obtain structure-dynamics-function information on these metallopeptides under native-like conditions. The project will focus on model membranes to accurately and precisely control membrane composition and directly relate their molecular contents to specific functional and conformational behaviors of host defense metallopeptides and their interactions with bilayers. The project will feature assays on live cells relevant to the biological context of the chosen host defense peptides to investigate the contribution of lipid oxidation to the antimicrobial potency of the peptides, identify synergistic effects among peptides, and relate biological potencies to physicochemical properties. This project will generate multiple broad impact outcomes. First, the new findings and methodologies created will contribute to advancing scientific knowledge in the fields of membrane biophysics, structural biology, immunology, and biochemistry. These fundamental principles could be useful to design novel antimicrobial agents and biomaterials. Second, the scientific environment will foster partnerships between academia and national labs. Third, the outreach activities will stimulate the interest of college and pre-college students from diverse backgrounds in hands-on science, and enhance their analytical skills.

por.por_cntn:
Antibiotic resistance is recognized to be a major public health threat worldwide. In the United States, it is responsible yearly for more than 2 million infections and tens of thousands of deaths. Most antibiotics have specific targets that bacteria can resist through mutations. In this collaborative project, the principal investigator Cotten (William & Mary) and her co-investigators Angeles-Boza (U Connecticut) and Mihailescu (University of Maryland, NIST Center for Neutron Research) bridged their complementary expertise to mechanistically investigate molecular systems that have novel properties to fight antibiotic resistance. First, we relied on host defense peptides, which have nonspecific targets such as bacterial cell membranes, and thus feature lower incidence of resistance. Second, we leveraged synergy among antimicrobial agents since this translates into reduced drug dosages, and thus lower risks for bacterial resistance.  

Gaining new insights into novel mechanisms of synergistic action is challenging for several reasons. First, combinations of antimicrobial agents that exhibit strong synergistic activity must be identified. Second, complementary biophysical methods must be leveraged to characterize under physiologically-relevant conditions the structures and mechanisms of the synergistic agents. Third, activity assays must be performed under changing conditions, so that meaningful structure-function relationships can be established.  

The investigators combined cutting-edge biophysical techniques and biological assays to understand how host defense peptides synergize with other antimicrobial agents to target pathogenic membranes. The main activities and findings of our research project are summarized as follows:

1)     The first level of synergy that we investigated was between copper ions and piscidins, which are host defense peptides from fish.

  • We found that copper binding to the amino terminal copper and nickel motif of piscidins enhances their antimicrobial and membrane activity. This effect correlates with the deeper membrane insertion that the peptides achieved upon metallation. Using high resolution structural methods, we revealed that strong interactions exist between the metal ion and aromatic chains in the peptides. The presence of aromatic rings near metal binding sites is relevant to a wide range of other membrane-binding peptides that are biologically important, including other host defense peptides, neuropeptides, and amyloid peptides.
  • We revealed that the oxidized lipids, which can form in the presence of copper ions and copper-bound peptides, enhance the membrane activity of the peptide. This new knowledge could be useful to the studies of other membrane-active peptides (e.g., amyloid beta peptide; fusion peptides) that also form and/or encounter oxidized lipids as part of their biological function.
  • We demonstrated that the synergistic effects between piscidin and copper encompass not only antimicrobial but also anticancer action. The ability to achieve enhanced anticancer activity via metallation could have broader implications in the field of membrane biophysics and cancer biology.

2)     Another level of synergy that we explored was between piscidins and glycolipids. We discovered strong antimicrobial synergy between piscidins and sophorolipids, which are glycolipids derived from non-pathogenic yeasts. These synergistic effects are based on the ability of the glycolipid micelles to pre-fold piscidins into their active α-helical state and deliver large amounts to bacterial cell membranes. This opens new avenues of research to activate antimicrobial peptides and deliver them to the site of action.

3)     We also investigated how the physical properties of membranes influence the membrane activity of piscidins. We found that piscidins leverage membrane heterogeneity as part of their mechanism of action. In particular, when cholesterol is present, the peptides push it away and concentrate themselves in the cholesterol-depleted regions. This results in enhanced membrane activity. We have investigated this mechanistic feature in the context of viral envelopes.   

Overall, our research has helped identify mechanisms employed by naturally-occurring agents to achieve broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity. In particular, we have revealed that combining host defense peptides with copper and glycolipids affords strong synergistic antimicrobial action. The underlying mechanisms that we identified, including enhanced delivery method, membrane insertion, and disruption of bilayer phase behaviors, are relevant to other biological systems.

In terms of broader impacts, the funding received from the NSF for this collaborative grant has helped the Cotten group grow its expertise in membrane biophysics. It has strengthened the collaboration between the Angeles-Boza, Cotten, and Mihailescu groups. It has also provided a fertile ground of concepts and methods for other researchers in the field. During the funding period, we published 10 articles. In terms of education and training at William & Mary, this project provided opportunities for three Ph.D. students and twelve undergraduates to learn concepts and techniques in membrane biophysics. Seven high school students were also engaged in the summer. PI Cotten created an interdisciplinary capstone lab-based course that gave hands-on opportunities to students on projects investigating structure-function relationships in membrane-interacting peptides.
